solution:
Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\  z \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 & -1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 4 & 0 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\  z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 27 \\ -14 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations
\begin{align*}
2x + 3y - z &= 2, \\
4y + 5z &= 27, \\
4x - 2z &= -14.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $x = -2,$ $y = 3,$ and $z = 3,$ so $\mathbf{v} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 3 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
model_solution:
## Step 1: Write the given matrix equation in the form of $\mathbf{Av} = \mathbf{b}$.
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 & -1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 4 & 0 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 27 \\ -14 \end{pmatrix}.\]

## Step 2: Write the augmented matrix $\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right]$ by combining $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{b}$.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 & -1 & | & 2 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 & | & 27 \\ 4 & 0 & -2 & | & -14 \end{pmatrix}.\]

## Step 3: Perform Gaussian elimination to transform the augmented matrix to row-echelon form.
Performing row operations to get the row-echelon form:
- Divide the first row by
## Step 4: Divide the first row by 2 to get a leading 1.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{3}{2} & -\frac{1}{2} & | & 1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 & | & 27 \\ 4 & 0 & -2 & | & -14 \end{pmatrix}.\]
## Step 5: Perform $R_3 - 4R_1$ to eliminate the entry below the leading 1 in the first column.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{3}{2} & -\frac{1}{2} & | & 1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 & | & 27 \\ 0 & -6 & -4 & | & -30 \end{pmatrix}\]
## Step 6: Perform $R_3 + 6R_2$ to get a leading 1 in the second row, second column.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{3}{2} & -\frac{1}{2} & | & 1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 & | & 27 \\ 0 & 0 & -34 & | & -222 \end{pmatrix}\]
## Step 7: Perform $R_2 \div 4$ to get a leading 1 in the second row, second column.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{3}{2} & -\frac{1}{2} & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & \frac{5}{4} & | & \frac{27}{4} \\ 0 & 0 & -34 & | & -222 \end{pmatrix}\]
## Step 8: Perform $R_1 - \frac{3}{2}R_2$ and $R_1 + \frac{1}{2}R_3$ to eliminate the entries below the leading 1 in the first column.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & -2 & | & \frac{7}{4} \\ 0 & 1 & \frac{5}{4} & | & \frac{27}{4} \\ 0 & 0 & -34 & | & -222 \end{pmatrix}\]
## Step 9: Perform $R_1 + 2R_3$ and $R_2 - \frac{5}{34}R_3$ to get a leading 1 in the third row, third column.
\[\left[\mathbf{A}|\mathbf{b}\right] = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & | & -\frac{167}{34} \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & | & \frac{119}{34} \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & | & -6 \end{pmatrix}\]
## Step 10: From the row-echelon form, read off the solution to the system of linear equations.
\[\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{167}{34} \\ \frac{119}{34} \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}.\]
## Step 11: Final Answer:
\[\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{167}{34} \\ \frac{119}{34} \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}.\]
